results.name: Number of odd terms among n, f(n), f(f(n)), ...., 1 for the Collatz function (that is, until reaching "1" for the first time), or -1 if 1 is never reached.
comment: The Collatz function (related to the "3x+1 problem") is defined by: f(n) = n/2 if n is even; f(n) = 3n + 1 if n is odd. A famous conjecture states that n, f(n), f(f(n)), .... eventually reaches 1.
The count includes also the starting value n if it is odd. See A286380 for the version which never includes n itself. - _Antti Karttunen_, Aug 10 2017

Index entries for sequences related to 3x+1 (or Collatz) problem
example: The terms n, f(n), f(f(n)), ...., 1 for n = 12 are: 12, 6, 3, 10, 5, 16, 8, 4, 2, 1, of which 3 are odd. Hence a(12) = 3.
mathematica: f[n_] := Module[{a, i, o}, i = n; o = 1; a = {}; While[i > 1, If[Mod[i, 2] == 1, o = o + 1]; a = Append[a, i]; i = f[i]]; o]; Table[f[i], {i, 1, 100}]
program: (PARI) a(n) = {my(x=n, v=List([])); while(x>1, if(x%2==0, x=x/2, listput(v, x); x=3*x+1)); 1+#v;} \\ _Jinyuan Wang_, Dec 29 2019
